instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: the board does just like the older mac board used to do. The fan slowly ramps to full speed and it's laggy.  Is there an smc bypass procedure for the newer models?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: Do you have known good battery connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: Start in diagnostic mode and check what errors pop up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message:
Test with known good trackpad board/flex.
Also try disconnecting camera flex from T-CON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>I2C_TPAD_3V3_SCL</SIGNAL> is 1.466 and <SIGNAL>I2C_TPAD_3V3_SDA</SIGNAL> is 0.958  . i remember you telling me that  the readings on a data bus line should almost match.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message:
Too big difference; check on the other side of <TRANSISTOR>Q6861</TRANSISTOR> too.
Inspect <RESISTOR>R6877</RESISTOR>/8 and <RESISTOR>R6812</RESISTOR>/3.

Did you check in diode mode w/ and w/o trackpad connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: those reading are without the trackpad cable connected.  <SIGNAL>I2C_TPAD_3V3_SDA</SIGNAL> reads the same on a known working board. <SIGNAL>I2C_SENSE_SCL</SIGNAL> seems to be culprit. <SIGNAL>I2C_SENSE_SCL</SIGNAL>  is 1.992 and <SIGNAL>I2C_SENSE_SDA</SIGNAL> is 0.471  in diode mode to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: do you know if <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> has one or two layers of solder on this model?  i'll attempt to reball it if there is just one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: i've replaced that <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> chip with another one. now the amp meter shows 20v 0.000a with a charged battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message:
You should use SoC ROM (<CHIP>U4770</CHIP>) from the same board of the "new" T2.
Also need DFU restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message: when jumpering <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL>, can i solder the jumper before applying power or only after applying power?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thermal sensor issue
threads.message:
You must solder wire before applying power.
Cut it off as soon as machine enters into DFU mode.
